Oh, sorry for not providing any good context here ;)

My real goal is to ge=
t parallelization of *any* sort running within maven2. This is because our =
automated build uses it; if I was able to get parallel test-methods it'd cu=
t the run-time of our long-running builds to about a third. If I could get =
classes too I'd probably aim for world-record swamping of our 16-core build=
 server ;) Reducing wall-clock execution time of all our builds is a priori=
ty concern.

For our daily work we use IntelliJ idea v8, and while certainl=
y "nice to have" the value of parallel tests in the development environment=
 is less glaringly obvious. 

I was looking around in the git-snapshot of j=
unit-4.7 code, trying to determine how/if I could do this. It seems to me l=
ike there's two basic approaches as to how to achieve this:

To get paralle=
lization for classes you need to mess around with the runner. I'm not total=
ly familiar/comfortable with how this would be done. 

For parallel methods=
 it seems like one *should* be able to specify a "Computer" on the "@RunWit=
h" annotation; it even seems like a logical configuration point for this in=
formation. 

I know this may be slightly off-topic, but I feel several "ten=
sions" in the code-base around the "Computer". Is this still largely work i=
n progress?

Kristian






--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, David Saff <david=
@...> wrote:
>
> Kristian,
> 
> 1) Can you use the 4.7 snapshot?
> 2) Are y=
ou trying to parallelize methods within a class, classes
> within a suite, =
or both?
> 3) What are you using to run the tests?
> 
>    David Saff
> 
> =
On Thu, Jun 18, 2009 at 6:07 AM, krosenvold<kristian@...> wrote:
> > Using =
a RunnerBuilder and a Computer, the JUNIT 4.7 Request class creates the Run=
ner object.
> >
> > I am currently using @RunWith(SpringJUnit4ClassRunner.c=
lass) (from spring 3.0 rc) and I'm trying to shoehorn parallel running into=
 this regime, but it seems to me like these two designs are now fairly orth=
ogonal. I suppose it could have been solved by amending a "Computer" to the=
 @RunWith tag, and I also suppose I may be trying to solve this problem at =
the incorrect level.
> >
> > Anyone have any thoughts/suggestions on this o=
ne ?
> >
> > Kristian Rosenvold
